awd_titl_txt: High-Dimensional Phenomena, Limit Theorems, and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The project's research covers several topics in mathematics and is focused on the study of probabilistic, geometric, and information-theoretic aspects of high dimensional phenomena, including concentration of measure and asymptotic behavior of various functions of a growing number of random variables. The concentration tools are the subject of many exciting developments, since they help explore most essential properties of general complex systems where randomness of their numerous small parts results in a stable limit behavior. Being connected with challenging mathematical problems, this research area has proved to be very useful for applications in other fields such as statistics, information theory, computer science, machine learning. One of the objectives of the project is to clarify the role of growing dimension as a unifying source in high-dimensional models and, in particular, its influence on the entire evolution in time as opposed to local rules. Proposed research will have a broader impact by creating new connections between different mathematical fields and providing them with powerful interdisciplinary tools. The project will also have an important impact on educating in mathematical sciences.
 
More specifically, the investigator intends to develop new advanced concentration tools for spaces with sufficiently many symmetries including Grassmanian manifolds. It is planned to apply them in the study of global properties of multidimensional projections for log-concave and more general hyperbolic measures, that are related to the thin shell (variance) problem and the K-L-S conjecture of Kannan, Lovasz and Simonovits. Another sort of applications deals with randomized models of summation for dependent data under correlation conditions. Part of the project is devoted to limit theorems and asymptotic expansions in the central limit theorem for information-theoretic distances such as the relative entropy (Kullback-Leibler distance) and relative Fisher information, which  
will be accompanied by proper Berry-Esseen bounds. The project also deals with Edgeworth-type expansions and informational bounds in the problem of Poisson approximation. The proposed themes refer either to long-standing open problems or to challenging questions related to recent developments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The research outcome of the project may be classified according to several topics and goals. The PI continued to explore new concentration tools and develop their applications in the area of limit theorems in Probability and Information Theory. One of such tools refines the well-known spherical concentration phenomenon which may be stated informally as follows: Any smooth function on the high dimensional sphere is almost constant on a large part of the sphere. Certain rigorous forms/statements of this fundamental property have been previosly studied by the PI and co-authors (G. Chistyakov and F. Goetze). In the project they were intensively exploited in order to quantify Sudakov's variant of the central limit theorem (CLT). The latter postulates that the distribution of a large number of small summands almost does not depend on the summands and approaches a certain typical distribution expressed as a mixture of Gaussian (normal) laws on the real line. Results in this direction obtained under the project extend the previous contributions by B. Klartag and S. Sodin (2012) to the scheme of not necessarily independent random variables.


Another part of the project dealt with approximation problems about empirical measures constructed for a large number of independent observations on the plane and in other Euclidean spaces. To this aim, the PI and his co-author (M. Ledoux) proposed a new analytic tool based on the Fourier transformation of measures. In applications, this tool allows one to effectively control the transport distance from the empirical measure to the (unknown) true distribution. As a simple consequence, there has been found a new proof for the famous AKT theorem due to Ajtai, Komlos and Tusnady (1984).


Part of the project was devoted to the study of integral characteristics of probability distributions known as information-theoretic quantities, such as entropy and scores. The PI has found natural conditions which gauarantee the finitness of the moments (L^p-norms) of the scores for sums of independent random variables. The problem of finiteness of the moments goes back to the work by P.-L. Lions and G. Toscani (1995) who studied the CLT in Sobolev spaces and, in one particular case, to E. Gabetta (1994) in the context of the kinetic theory of gases for the convergence to equilibrium in Kac?s model.


Together with A. Marsiglietti and J. Melbourne, there have been studied discrete variants of the entropy power inequality in the class of lattice log-concave probability distributions. Containing a lot of open questions, this line of reseach has become a classical part in Information Theory. In another investigation, the PI proved a local limit theorem in Orlicz spaces, so that to unite several classical results including Barron's entropic CLT (1986).
